allsearch_rails_api.title: Benchmark Direct Solr vs. Blacklight JSON API Queries

comments.body:
Questions:
- how many VMs for each environment? - In the spirit of redundancy, let's start with two servers for each environment unless there are limitations. 
- how much CPU/memory/storage? - Storage needs are low for this application. The server will contain only code, config files, and any associated logging. For the current production library web servers we have them resourced at 40GB local disk space, 16GB RAM, and 2 cpus. That seems like a reasonable starting place. 
- what to name them (allsearch_prod1? How about allsearch_api-staging1,2 and allsearch-api-prod1,2.
URIs: allsearch-api.princeton.edu and allsearch-api-staging.princeton.edu

allsearch_rails_api.title: Communicate directly with solr for catalog and dpul

comments.body: _What is the best way to set up a dev environment? Create an SSH tunnel? Or have a bunch of solr collections running locally in lando?_: For a dev environment it would be better to use lando and have solr colelctions running locally.

> - Why is the findingaids [blacklight API response](https://github.com/pulibrary/allsearch_rails_api/blob/df921d6d11d5581691e34bd33ab2db92e26cc957/spec/fixtures/files/findingaids/cats.json) so different than the [solr API response](https://github.com/pulibrary/allsearch_rails_api/blob/df921d6d11d5581691e34bd33ab2db92e26cc957/spec/fixtures/files/solr/findingaids/cats.json)?  Which is preferable?

I don't know exactly why the sort is so different, but my best guess that it has to do with the CatalogController and sort behavior. 

I think it's important that the sort match between the Allsearch and the specific service's default search, because I think otherwise it will be very disorienting for users. This also gives the service application developers more fine-grained control over search result sorting. 

I understand the desire to hit the Solr API directly, for speed and load, but I think specifically re-creating the Solr queries the different Blacklight apps create will be time consuming, and would be very prone to drift. I think there's similar risk for breaking changes between the Blacklight apps and hitting Solr directly.

> specifically re-creating the Solr queries the different Blacklight apps create will be time consuming

Almost all of the complexity in what Orangelight sends to Solr is related to facets, which we wouldn't need to recreate for this application.  Of the [52 lines in this query, for example](https://github.com/pulibrary/solr_load_testing/blob/main/sample_kw_response.json#L6-L58), only one has to do with the sort order.  And I'd be happy to add a sort param to my PR.

Not sure if this is true of the other applications as well.

```
What is the best way to set up a dev environment? Create an SSH tunnel? Or have a bunch of solr collections running locally in lando?
```
Creating four local local collections in solr for all four of these applications seems like a lot to manage and build. For local dev purposes couldn't we just query the staging or qa environments (regardless of using solr or the blacklight api) of these applications when the application is running in dev mode.

comments.body:
> @ishasinha1 can you please change the lux-design-system version in package.json to reflect version 4.5.1 ? I would change it to `"lux-design-system": "^4.5.1",` so that it will accept new minor and patch versions. Then `yarn install` will update the yarn.lock. We want the version we are using to be visible in package.json.

update in the previous comment. We want the version we are using to be in package.json as well as any other dependencies.

orangelight.title: Restrict automatic Google thumbnail import for Special Collections print materials records

comments.body:
Update: my previous alert to books-library-support@google.com has remained not addressed for 3 months. Today I sent another cover mismatch alert, responding to a patron's report via [LibAnswers](https://faq.library.princeton.edu/admin/ticket?qid=12267996).
![image](https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/assets/54282275/d198e778-2984-4591-a445-000e48b910b4)

This time I found a local solution without having to rely on Google Books. Because the cover image of our own copy has been scanned and stored in Figgy, I added a 856 ark address to the bib, and this overrode the mismatched cover fed by Google. The takeaway is, when push comes to shove, we can scan our own cover to block out the wrong image.

comments.body: Our current nagios-based [monitoring system for rack temp and humidity](https://varanus.princeton.edu/centreon) is only accessible from Windows jump-hosts. It is ancient and would need upgrading to serve as a multi-purpose monitoring platform. Docs are in [Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1OSEhKBWJaZsGbBZ-d3HNLCgW_Ju3aKCA).

princeton_ansible.title: Use a template for our simplest nginx configs

comments.body:
A quick look at a few config files uncovers a few differences among sites. Known needed changes:
- [ ] add a var for the HTTP [load-balancing technique](https://www.nginx.com/blog/choosing-nginx-plus-load-balancing-techniques/) (see annotations-prod)
- [ ] add a section for enabling/disabling `app_protect` (see abid-staging)
- [ ] allow more than one included `restrict` file (see bibdata-qa)
- [ ] regularize an `ansible-managed` comment

With these changes done, we can try using the template for these sites:
- [ ] abid
- [ ] annotations
- [ ] ansible-tower
- [ ] approvals
- [ ] bibdata
- [ ] byzantine-tsp
- [ ] cicognara
- [ ] eal-apps
. . . and probably more.

Once the changes are ready, we can put the vars in place and create the templated files in `/tmp/`, then diff the files against the actual nginxplus config files to identify any changes/drift.
Audit complete, no immediate actions needed.
